data.title: Blue Lamp – Sacramento Music Archive
data.meta_description: Posts about Blue Lamp written by shaynestacy
data.text:
I am cleaning and archiving hundreds of multicam MP4’s from my hard drive, and I stumbled across this one. We never posted it at the time, then I forgot about it. This is a special show with Kepi, B-Face AND Roy McDonald from the Muffs doing a full band set! Great set full of Kepi and Ghoulies classics.

On a side note, I was going to ask Roy about The Muffs and when they were going to tour, but I got busy filming MTX… Kim passed away a couple weeks after this show. It was probably for the best that I missed him.

This show was mixed before I had the ability to matrix my own audio, or rebelance it in Izotope… the mix is “OK”, but it could have been better. Oh well.

Recorded by: Shayne Stacy

Equipment used: Canon HFG40 x2, Gopro Hero4 Silver x3.

Soundboard audio via Sony PCM-M10 through the soundboard.

Motorcycle is a new band with Chris Sabatoni from The Croissants, Kortnee Barnett Angel on bass, and Sarah Sintaku on drums.

I missed the first song because I was talking to friends, and right when I got my camera going, the next song was a false start. Don’t hold that against them, they are really good!

Recorded by: Shayne Stacy

Equipment Used: Canon HFG40 & Rode Videomic Pro Stereo

It was nice to see the Mean Jeans in a bigger room. They have only played smaller places in Sac before. I thought that I pushed the soundboard remix a little too hard and caused some distortion, but this sounds pretty clean.

Recorded by: Shayne Stacy

Equipment: Canon HFG40 x2, Gopro hero4 silver x3

Video Enhancement/denoise in Adobe Premiere Elements

Audio remix in Izotope RX7

Edit by Tromster

My wife & I went on another date night to the Verbal Abuse & MDC show. Jesse Davis was there with a few of his cameras so I took the night off. I contributed the soundboard audio to the mix. Here’s 2 songs from that show.

Recorded by: Jesse Davis (+ 1 other camera guy)

Equipment used: 4 camera edit. Sound Matrix is 2 sony mics, 1 realistic, a zoom h4n, and stereo soundboard by shayne stacy.

Edit by: Jesse Davis

With Ben & Gabi announcing the sale of the Blue Lamp, I thought it would be nice to remind people of the good times there. Thanks to you both & AJ & Chris for putting up with empty shows for so long.

OK, on to this show. Flipper was NOT empty. In fact, the show was sold out. It was a killer show, and I really want to thank Stephen for giving permission to film- very nice of you.

Here are the details: Recorded by: Shayne Stacy

Video Equipment used: Canon HFG40 x2, Gopro Hero4 silver x3(enhanced in adobe permiere + neat video)

Audio Equipment used: Sony PCM-M10 through the soundboard + Rode Videomic Pro Stereo audience

Audio Matrix: Shayne Stacy (my first one ever!)

Edit by: Tromster

Sound engineer: Andrew Scott

I have seen Frack about 5 times now and this was their best set I have seen. You could tell that they were pretty happy to be opening the sold-out Flipper show. The new songs sound great, while keeping in the best of the older ones. Features the crowd pleasing Rise Above cover, like you’ve never heard before!

Recorded by: Shayne Stacy

Equipment used: Canon HF G40 & Rode Videomic Pro Stereo

I’ve had this new role at my old job that has been super demanding. I had conference calls scheduled late on the same night that The Authorities played Blue Lamp. I wasn’t going to let that stop me. I took the call in the car while parked outside the venue, then ran in and scrambled to set 5 cameras up before they started. It came out pretty good considering the circumstances.

This is the era of Blue Lamp lighting that had cycling colors, which would overexpose the video in parts, and be so dark it was hard to see in others. It was still not too bad.

Recorded by: Shayne Stacy

Equipment used: Canon HFG40 x2, Gopro Hero 4 Silver x3

Audio equipment: Rode Videomic Pro stereo on HFG40 + Sony M10 through the soundboard, matrixed in Sony Sound Forge

Video noise reduction in Adobe premiere/neat video

Edit by tromster
